comments.commentBody:
I could not agree more. Good essay by Mr. Rattner as well.

The IRS has the legal basis to charge Apple, Mr. Cook, other executives and the Apple board of directors criminally liable for tax evasion.

Fraudulent transfer pricing for the purpose of evading taxes is just that fraudulent, where there is no economic or business basis for the tax accounting. The sole purpose - not only that but the purpose could not be any more glaringly obvious - is to evade income taxation in the USA. That is a crime, particularly given the amounts involved.

If the Obama Administration had some slight courage, it would instruct the IRS to indict Apple, Mr. Cook, the CFO, the head of taxes there and the entire board of directors as criminals. That action alone would change the tune of other companies engaging in the same activity.

At the same time the Obama Administration should put massive pressure of any and all kinds on the Irish government that will cost it much more than continuing to act as a partner in crime to these companies. The Irish government has everything to lose and it knows it.

Mr. Obama, Mr. Lew: show a modicum of courage. The bulk of the USA population is behind you.

Maybe Apple doesn't do anything illegal, or not too much. But that's not even the point. What is more the point is that big companies like Apple can get away with it and actually are dictating the tax code that allows this to be legal in the first place. This was really well illustrated in the Senate hearing, where, instead of slamming Apple for not paying it's fair share of taxes (yes, fair share, whether it's legal or not), the senators declared their love for Apple and asked it to tell them how the tax code should be changed. This is the most sickening part. This is not democracy, it's corporatocracy. And that's what Apple does, it subverts democracy, going straight against the constitution.
RLS, you conveniently did not include the following line from the WSJ article you linked to - "The investigation found no evidence that Apple did anything illegal."
DF - When an entity fails to file tax returns, that's illegal!!!

Apple does nothing illegal.  Apple does its best to minimize taxes according to the tax rules set up by the senators doing the questioning.  Apple is doing the right thing for shareholders and I applaud them for it. The fool politicians who invented the rules have no right to criticize Apple for using them.
The highly popular delusion that a country that can print its own currency can never go bankrupt keeps certain troublesome ideas from surfacing too often.

Politicians can't "raise wages"; market demand for labor raises wages.

As a result of the weak yen, it is no longer true that Korea etc are building cheaper exports. http://qz.com/79583/japans-industrial-gains-from-abenomics-come-at-the-e...

I've been living in Japan for 15 years, and I must admit I'm not a fan of Abe due to his strong nationalistic tendencies and the fact that he is just another cog in the wheel of the old political establishment. I do, however, think it's great that he has at least gotten Japan back on the radar screens of the world....for a long time it seemed as though no one was paying attention.

But all this enthusiasm about Japan feels a bit hollow... When the enthusiasm wanes, how is he going to raise wages in a country where they have steadily declined as corporations hoard cash on their balances sheets? How is he going to change the very core of the social fabric that discriminates against women and makes it impossible for them to fully contribute to a majority of Japanese companies? I'm not seeing the real "meat and potatoes" here. A weak yen can only take this country so far, especially when Korea, Taiwan and China are already building cheaper exports of nearly equal quality...

I, too, think Deb made some points, but I also think she tore into a pretty enjoyable puzzle. I think, furthermore, that she has come down hard on more than few puzzles lately—more than we've come to expect from her and, IMO, more than is justified.

My only beef with this puzzle is the compound Natick in the SW corner—the crossing of 48 and 49D with 62 and 65A. I was able to guess at 48D and then 62A but needed Mlle Check to show me I was right; then I guessed again at the last letter of 49D, and the good lady told me I got it wrong. Those four squares cost me an unassisted win, and on a Friday, at that. Bah!

Neville Chamberlain at the rate he's going.
But in fairness, I've never seen such an epic and rabid witch hunt in all my fifty years. I thought Clinton got the worst treatment I'd ever seen back in the nineties until this. But I guess it's just a pattern and the next Dem in the White House will get it even worse from this band of sociopaths we call the GOP.

As much as I hate to say it Mr. Obama is one of them! Remember Bush 2 saying your eather with us or against us well there you have it in a nut shell. It would seem the powers at be will only give us a choice of one of them or one of them.

Permitting myself a digression from the major topic of this column by Prof. Krugman: "Republicans only seem to want to talk about fake scandals."

Fake is the word! We are indebted to Dr. Krugman for shouting out "The King is Naked!, when no one who should (journalists, maybe?) dares say so. For was it not the job of the IRS, indeed, to flush out political organizations seeking illegitimate tax exemption status as "community service" groups? So then, if most if not all such groups were Tea Party attendants, is the IRS not to do anything for fear of being accused of partisanship?

President Obama chose, once again, not to take a firm position that would have easily justified, and rightly so, the focus of the IRS to properly investigate the legitimacy of such claims for tax exempt status.

But Mr. Obama's proverbial avoidance of a firm stance on anything that may require open confrontation may prove to be, sadly, his infelicitous presidential legacy.

I don't believe FDR lived to see any positive economic results from his policies at all.  Basically, the productive world (except for the USA) was destroyed during WWII.  We had tremendous austerity during the war years (rationing, metal collecting drives, no rubber for tires, victory gardens and on and on).  When the war ended, we were the only people with a functional infrastructure.  We made the most of having all of our competition destroyed, and we managed to lead the world economically for the next 50 years.  Unfortunately, we thought our lead was due to something fundamental in our nature instead of the destruction of our competitors.  Thus our current inability to see our true situation, and the resulting inability to keep our lead growing in a world again populated by competitors with ideas, education and resources.  We are now stupid, fat and slow, and other countries will be kicking our butts ever more often in the future.  Ever notice how our high school kids rank compared to other countries?  We're pitiful and too proud to admit the truth.

As the mastermind of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto is said to have observed in the wake of success that he feared that all Japan had accomplished was to awaken a sleeping giant and fill it with a terrible resolve.

One can argue, and I will, that the pervasive economic problem that has been imprisoning Japan is tantamount to those restrictive boundaries it felt unjust but required by western nations that led its most conservative leaders to demand and achieve World War II.

In this current case Japan can be said to have done exactly the opposite, and right thing, attacking the fundamental problem that has bound it, its arbitary selection of policies that decades have proven to be ineffective.

Interestingly, the policies proven to work in the United States in the years preceding World War II are those that Japan, with modern tweaks, is practicing, and from which, like FDR, is seeing positive results.

Admiral Yamamoto, intimately familiar with the capabilities of the U.S. would approve. Paraphrased he would suggest that Japan had finally attacked the correct sleeping giant, itself, and filled it with the resolve Japanese culture and history reveal to be harbored in its people: the ability to achieve what others resign themselves to assuming is impossible.
.

Zero population growth has downsides as well; for example few Japanese workers are supporting far more retirees (which is also the growing problem with the US social security system). In general, the minuses tend to outweigh the pluses.
Regardless, population growth has exactly zero to do with the question whether or not fiscal stimulus is effective.

Dear Mr. Hansen,

Having lived in Oklahoma for most of my life, I have strong opinions on the questions you raise.

In my opinion, the whole concept of an above-ground "safe room" is flawed. They are of more psychological value than actual physical protection.

Such safe rooms are of use only in EF1-3 tornadoes.

If struck by an EF4 or EF5 tornado, forget it. The "safe room" will be swept away with the rest of the structure.

Very little is safe above ground in an EF5 tornado.

The key is to get underground.

Those who shelter in below-grade storm cellars will survive even the worst tornadoes.

Those who shelter in basements will usually survive bad tornadoes.

However, basements are not totally safe. If the house collapses on top of you, you may have some ado to get out of a basement with several tons of debris dumped into it.

I am told that, tragically, some of the fatalities in the Moore EF5 were teachers and children trapped in the school basement, unable to get out, which then flooded due to burst water mains.

Get thee underground, I say. Dig a storm cellar and be damned to the price. It is worth it.
If you say "Jiff" you probably have never made a "gif".

Sheldon, everything you say is right on but it ain't gonna happen. As long as we depend on elections based on who spends the most money it will be business as usual in congress and the executive branch. Citizens United needs to be overturned. So in the end we need a return to 1930's take to the streets activism along with people willing to strike and unionize.
No more going along to get along. Only in-your-face activism will put fear into the 1% and force them to at least throw us some bones.

Sheldon, Great Comment. The #1 action needed is expansion of the number of representatives in the peoples house. 435 for 100 years is to few.

@ Ed Lipton, It must happen - It can be done now. By changing the nature of the strike to focus on the means of production in today's economy. Stop buying stuff. Boycott. Buycott.com. A national day of savings were we stay out of stores especially gas stations would shake things up. Once a week would have a huge impact until they start paying attention to their customers.

They can't bring in scabs to break this kind of strike. The UBA - United Buyers of America. We need to buy our country back. Stop the Walton's, Koch's and especially the dime store Pope's.

In 2010 the GOP ran on jobs, jobs, jobs. Where were the jobs? Hadn’t we extended the Bush tax cuts for the job providers? What we got was bills on abortion and repealing of Obamacare and hysterics about spending. The American Jobs Act was DOA. The uber-rich and tax avoiding big corporations and Wall Street siting on piles of un-invested cash decided that a good long dose of austerity would achieve their political goals of breaking the middle class and pauperizing everyone else into a pool of cheap day labor. The deficit has been substantially reduced, spending is down, ordinary citizens have been driven to the wall, banks seize homes whose mortgages a not in default, the 1% controls the House and the Senate and the president is wary of making war on Wall Street which is too powerful to prosecute for their frauds.

What needs to be done: (1) pass a comprehensive infrastructure replacement and act; (2) enact laws to make it more profitable to re-industrialize the US than export jobs or offshore work; (3) reinstate Glass-Steigal: (4) strictly enforce the Sherman Antitrust Act and the Wagner Act; raise the minimum wage to $12/hr for full time work and $15/hr for part time work and for net estates exceeding $100 million, tax total assets at 5%/yr; and (5) make it a felony to avoid taxes by holding untaxed sums offshore. This cannot be done before 2015 and it depends whether the voters want austerity or prosperity and whether we elect patriots or republicans.
Yes.  This is the pronunciation and the rationale I've always followed.
Ah, so it's really giraffic interchange format....

Well, "jigabyte" is apparently the officially correct way to say it, but it's a little silly when you try to sound cool by shortening it to "gigs." As in, "what's the capacity of your hard drive?" Two-hundred-fifty jigs." It sounds like something out of Riverdance.

Wait, does anyone actually listen to that rule? I thought everyone just hid their ipod/iphone/ipad/etc while the flight attendants walk the aisles and just took them out as soon as they (the flight attendants) sit down for takeoff. No? That's generally what I see on planes...

Oh, great. Now people like you are planning on telling me when I can sleep, too?

How about if I promise to wake up if we hit a flock of Canadian geese?

I'm opposed to phones on planes for the reason you cite.

But to tell people they can't use an e-book device like a Kindle is just silly.

Yes Apple seems to be busy dodging their taxes by doing things like selling ITunes using a European subsidiary so they don't have to pay taxes on their US Sales. Or building a $5 billion dollar monument to themselves and calling it the home office although all they do is outsource all their jobs.

Innovation died with Steve Jobs. Now all they have is a super highly paid CEO.
In our neighborhood the kids (tweens/teens) want the Galaxy S4, not the current iPhone. Interesting on how Apple seems to be losing a little steam in the brand department.

Good question. Both NASA and Boeing have found that portable electronics CAN interfere with avionics. For example, see:

http://www.adn.com/2013/05/16/2904576/passenger-gizmos-blamed-for-interf...
'J-pheg' makes more sense than 'jif' for GIF.

If my audience is ignorant, I pronounce GIF with a soft 'G', because they will understand. If I suspect my audience is older and/or less ignorant, I pronounce it with a hard 'G', so there is no confusion with a JIF (or JIFF) file, which means JPEG image file format. GIF has not been pronounced as JIF by anyone who knows the difference.
One more indication that programmers don't know how to speak.
3D printing does seem vastly underestimated.  Let's not forget McKinsey's 1980 recommendation to AT&T that cell phones would be a niche market.
Think about it people. If you have to spell it 'Jif' to get the pronunciation right, then it's obviously pronounced 'Gif'.

Has anyone noticed that a lot of the careers that are seen as "women's work" or are staffed primarily by women - nursing, childcare, daycare, teaching at elementary to high school levels, lower level admin work, cleaning, retail work, etc... - are paid lower salaries or are being automated/mechanized away?
